case_vignette: A 60-year-old man presents with rapidly growing lesions on his face, trunk, axillae, flexural areas, and groin. The lesions appeared 3 months earlier in his perianal area and extended rapidly to other areas. Previously, he was treated with topical agents for atopic dermatitis and seborrheic dermatitis without improvement. Examination reveals disseminated violaceous papules and plaques on the face, trunk, axillae, and perianal area; some lesions were confluent and ulcerated. Yellowish-red to skin-colored papules are present on the scalp. He has no palpable lymphadenopathy or organomegaly.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have rapidly growing lesions on my face, trunk, and groin areas, which started around three months ago in my perianal area and spread to other areas.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 60-year-old man.
Do these lesions itch, burn, or have any discharge?
No, the lesions do not itch, burn, or have any discharge.
Have you been experiencing any other symptoms such as fever, weight loss, or night sweats?
No, I haven't experienced fever, weight loss, or night sweats.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you currently on any medications?
I have been treated previously for atopic dermatitis and seborrheic dermatitis using topical agents.
Do you have a history of any immune system disorders or malignancies in your family?
I'm sorry, but I don't have information on my family history regarding immune system disorders or malignancies.
Have the lesions changed in color or developed a crust or scale?
Some of the lesions on my face and other areas have become confluent and ulcerated.
Final Diagnosis: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (Mycosis Fungoides)
